Vectors

ag

Load tidyverse

Code 
# get tidyverse to shut up
suppressPackageStartupMessages({
  library(tidyverse)
  library(lubridate)
  library(magrittr)
})
Code 
# create a bib file for the R packages
# used in this document
# Note! Needs to do a touch ag_functions.bib in terminal before first run
# else stops when bibliography: "ag_functions.bib" not found in YAML
knitr::write_bib(
  c(
    "tidyverse",
    "lubridate",
    "magrittr"
    ),
  file = "ag_vectors.bib"
  )

Define my_df and my_dates

  • define my_df and my_dates from previous lecture (code not shown)
Code 
set.seed(333)
my_df <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(10, mean = 100, sd = 10),
  y = runif(10, min = 30, max = 130),
  z = rlnorm(10, 2, 2)
)
set.seed(1234)
my_dates <- tibble(
  y = 1999:2008,
  m = sample(1:12, size = 10, replace = TRUE),
  # make it simple, seed 1234 gives no impossible date
  d = sample(1:31, size = 10, replace = TRUE),
  date = make_date(year = y, month = m, day = d)
)

Vectors

  • 6 types of atomic vectors, 4 of importance to us
    • logical
    • integer (numeric)
    • double (numeric)
    • character
  • All data in an atomic vector is of the same type
  • Lists, can contain data of different kinds including other lists
  • NULL, absence of vector
    • behaves like a vector of length 0
  • NA, absence of element in vector

Vector properties

  • type, check type with typeof(my_df$x)
  • length, get length with length(my_df$x) > - has no dimension so dim(my_df$x) will give an error
  • augmented vectors, attributes used to give additional behaviour
    • factors built on integer
    • Date and date-times built on double
    • dataframes/tibbles built on lists
  • dataframes/tibbles are lists of vectors of the same length. The vectors can be of different type

Vector properties; code

Code 
class(my_df)
[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"
Code 
typeof(my_df)
[1] "list"
Code 
str(my_df)
tibble [10 × 3] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ x: num [1:10] 99.2 119.3 79.5 102.8 84.7 ...
 $ y: num [1:10] 43 37.1 49.1 56.8 81.7 ...
 $ z: num [1:10] 9.22 15.32 8.23 114.13 3.45 ...

More about vectors

  • Coercion, conversion from one type to another
  • Explicit: we convert with functions lik as.logical(), as.integer(), as.numeric(), as.double() and as.character()
    • Note! Many also have a new implementation in tidyverse.
    • tidyverse versions start with as_, i.e. _ instead of .
  • Implicit: use a vector in a context that demands a certain type of vector.
    • Classic example: sum(is.na(x)). is.na(x) returns TRUE or FALSE. sum() expect numeric input. TRUE and FALSE are converted on the fly to their numeric representations 1 and 0.
  • Do not use implicit conversion from integer to logical.
    • Example: if (length(x)) {}
    • Means: do something if length of x is not 0
    • It works, but harder to understand
    • Instead use: if (length(x) > 0) {}
  • General rule: The most complex type wins.

Some exsamples

  • General rule: The most complex type wins.
Code 
(x <- c(1, 4, 7, TRUE, "a"))
[1] "1"    "4"    "7"    "TRUE" "a"
Code 
typeof(x)
[1] "character"
Code 
(y <- c(1L, 1.5))
[1] 1.0 1.5
Code 
typeof(y)
[1] "double"

Naming elements in vector

  • Classic R names()
  • More modern: purrr:set_names() (imported from rlang)
Code 
(x <- 1:4)
[1] 1 2 3 4
Code 
# set names by nameing the element
x <- c(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3, d = 4)
x
a b c d 
1 2 3 4
Code 
# remove the names with set_names
x <- purrr::set_names(x, nm = NULL)
x
[1] 1 2 3 4
Code 
# set names again
x <- purrr::set_names(x, nm = c("a", "b", "c", "d"))
x
a b c d 
1 2 3 4

Naming elements in vector

Code 
# remove names
names(x) <- NULL
x
[1] 1 2 3 4
Code 
# set names again
x <- set_names(x, letters[1:4])
x
a b c d 
1 2 3 4
Code 
names(x) # get the names
[1] "a" "b" "c" "d"
Code 
# change one name
names(x)[[2]] <- "B"
x
a B c d 
1 2 3 4

Subsetting vectors

Code 
x <- letters[10:15]
x
[1] "j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o"
Code 
# pick elements 3 and 5
x[c(3,5)]
[1] "l" "n"
Code 
# name with capital letters
x <- purrr::set_names(x, nm = LETTERS[10:15])
x
  J   K   L   M   N   O 
"j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o"
Code 
# subset by name
x[c("J", "L", "M")]
  J   L   M 
"j" "l" "m"
Code 
# replicate elements
x[c("L", "L", "J", "L", rep("M", 4))]
  L   L   J   L   M   M   M   M 
"l" "l" "j" "l" "m" "m" "m" "m"

Subsetting vectors by dropping elements

Code 
x
  J   K   L   M   N   O 
"j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o"
Code 
# Drop elements, 1, 4 and 5
x[c(-1, -4, -5)]
  K   L   O 
"k" "l" "o"
Code 
# subsetting with logicals
x[c(TRUE, rep(FALSE,3), TRUE, FALSE)]
  J   N 
"j" "n"
Code 
(y <- c(TRUE, rep(FALSE,3), TRUE, FALSE))
[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE
Code 
x[y]
  J   N 
"j" "n"

Subsetting vectors by dropping elements

Code 
# we can not mix + and -
x[c(1, -4, 5)]

`Returns: Error in x[c(1, -4, 5)] : only 0’s may be mixed with negative subscripts

Subsetting with [[ and [

  • [[ extract only a single element
Code 
typeof(`[[`)
[1] "special"
Code 
typeof(`[`)
[1] "special"
Code 
x
  J   K   L   M   N   O 
"j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o"
Code 
x[1]
  J 
"j"
Code 
x[[1]]
[1] "j"

Subsetting with [[ and [

Code 
str(x[1])
 Named chr "j"
 - attr(*, "names")= chr "J"
Code 
str(x[[1]])
 chr "j"
Code 
typeof(x[1])
[1] "character"
Code 
typeof(x[[1]])
[1] "character"
Code 
names(x[1])
[1] "J"
Code 
names(x[[1]])
NULL

Subsetting dataframe with [[ and [

  • `df[row(s), column(s)]
  • One dimension not given returns all rows or columns
Code 
my_df1 <- my_df[1:3, ]
# column 1 all rows
my_df1[, 1]
# A tibble: 3 × 1
      x
  <dbl>
1  99.2
2 119. 
3  79.5
Code 
# row 3, all columns
my_df1[3, ]
# A tibble: 1 × 3
      x     y     z
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1  79.5  49.1  8.23

Subsetting dataframe with [[ and [

Code 
# element in row 3, column 3
my_df1[3, 3]
# A tibble: 1 × 1
      z
  <dbl>
1  8.23
Code 
my_df1[[3,3]]
[1] 8.22684
Code 
class(my_df1[3, 3])
[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"
Code 
typeof(my_df1[3, 3])
[1] "list"
Code 
class(my_df1[[3,3]])
[1] "numeric"

Subsetting dataframe with [[ and [

Code 
typeof(my_df1[[3,3]])
[1] "double"
Code 
# multiple elements [[]] gives an error
my_df1[[3,1:3]]
  • Error: Must extract column with a single valid subscript. x Subscript 1:3 has size 3 but must be size 1. Run rlang::last_error() to see where the error occurred.

Subsetting dataframe with [[ and [

  • Note the difference between [[ and [
    • [[ returns a single value
    • [ also returns a single value, but inside a dataframe/tibble
  • Very important for lists

Subsetting list with [[ and [

  • Note the difference between [[ and [
    • [[ returns a single value
    • [ also returns a single value, but inside a dataframe/tibble
  • Very important for lists
Code 
my_list <- list(letters[1:4], 1:3, "a", 1.25, TRUE)
str(my_list)
List of 5
 $ : chr [1:4] "a" "b" "c" "d"
 $ : int [1:3] 1 2 3
 $ : chr "a"
 $ : num 1.25
 $ : logi TRUE
Code 
my_list <- list(letters[1:4], list(1:3), list("a", 1.25, TRUE))
str(my_list)
List of 3
 $ : chr [1:4] "a" "b" "c" "d"
 $ :List of 1
  ..$ : int [1:3] 1 2 3
 $ :List of 3
  ..$ : chr "a"
  ..$ : num 1.25
  ..$ : logi TRUE

Subsetting list with [[ and [

Code 
my_list[2]
[[1]]
[[1]][[1]]
[1] 1 2 3
Code 
my_list[[2]]
[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3
Code 
str(my_list[2])
List of 1
 $ :List of 1
  ..$ : int [1:3] 1 2 3
Code 
str(my_list[[2]])
List of 1
 $ : int [1:3] 1 2 3

Subsetting list with [[ and [

  • named components
Code 
my_list <- list(A = letters[1:4], B = list(1, 2, 3), C = list("a", 1.25, TRUE))
str(my_list)
List of 3
 $ A: chr [1:4] "a" "b" "c" "d"
 $ B:List of 3
  ..$ : num 1
  ..$ : num 2
  ..$ : num 3
 $ C:List of 3
  ..$ : chr "a"
  ..$ : num 1.25
  ..$ : logi TRUE
Code 
l <- my_list[["C"]]
str(l)
List of 3
 $ : chr "a"
 $ : num 1.25
 $ : logi TRUE
Code 
l[[1]]
[1] "a"

Subsetting list with [[ and [

  • [[ trekker elementer opp av listen
Code 
l <- my_list[["B"]]
str(l)
List of 3
 $ : num 1
 $ : num 2
 $ : num 3
Code 
# The value
l[[1]]
[1] 1
Code 
# The value
my_list[["C"]][[2]]
[1] 1.25
Code 
# The value
my_list$C[[2]]
[1] 1.25

Subsetting list with [[ and [

  • See r4ds 20.5.3 Lists of condiments for a famous explanation of the difference between [[ and [.
Code 
# notice the difference
list(1:3)
[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3
Code 
list(c(1:3))
[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3
Code 
list(c(1, 2, 3))
[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3
Code 
list(c(1, 2, 3))[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3
Code 
list(1, 2, 3)[[1]]
[1] 1

Subsetting list with [[ and [

Code 
list(1, 2, 3)
[[1]]
[1] 1

[[2]]
[1] 2

[[3]]
[1] 3
Code 
list(1:3)[[1]][[2]]
[1] 2
Code 
list(1, 2, 3)[[2]]
[1] 2
Code 
unlist(my_list)
    A1     A2     A3     A4     B1     B2     B3     C1     C2     C3 
   "a"    "b"    "c"    "d"    "1"    "2"    "3"    "a" "1.25" "TRUE"
Code 
typeof(unlist(my_list))
[1] "character"
